Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. DT104 strain H11
Isolation Comments: derived isolates, we have used whole-genome sequencing to dissect the phylogenetic associations of the bacterium and its antimicrobial resistance genes through the course of an epidemic
Comments: 'Distinguishable epidemics of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 in different hosts.' Pubmed ID: 24030491. The global epidemic of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 provides an important example, both in terms of the agent and its resistance, of a widely disseminated zoonotic pathogen. Here, with an unprecedented national collection of isolates collected contemporaneously from humans and animals and including a sample of internationally derived isolates, we have used whole-genome sequencing to dissect the phylogenetic associations of the bacterium and its antimicrobial resistance genes through the course of an epidemic. Contrary to current tenets supporting a single homogeneous epidemic, we demonstrate that the bacterium and its resistance genes were largely maintained within animal and human populations separately and that there was limited transmission, in either direction. We also show considerable variation in the resistance profiles, in contrast to the largely stable bacterial core genome, which emphasizes the critical importance of integrated genotypic data sets in understanding the ecology of bacterial zoonoses and antimicrobial resistance.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain 142
Comments: Serotype diversity and Antimicrobial resistance among Salmonella enterica from patients at an equine referral hospital

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain B15CEB12
Comments: Salmonella enterica (non-Typhi) is one of the most common food-borne pathogens, primarily originating in agricultural animals, which can enter the food chain and cause salmonellosis in humans. Importantly a small number of serovars of Salmonella are responsible for the majority of cases of human salmonellosis. Salmonella enterica serovars typically exhibit a limited range of animal hosts, often referred to as serovar-host specificity. Swine, cattle, and poultry each carry different strains of Salmonella and only certain strains cause infectious disease in these hosts, with the remaining strains carried in a subclinical status or in a commensal relationship. In recent years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported a rise in human foodborne illnesses related to antibiotic resistant Salmonella enterica serovar I 4,[5], 12:i:- largely associated with the consumption of contaminated pork. Salmonella I 4,[5], 12:i:- is a serovar antigenically similar to Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium; however, it lacks the phase two flagellar antigen making it a monophasic variant.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain 3162
Comments: In this study we sequenced and assembled Salmonella genomes encompassing 7 serotypes isolated from poultry farms in Canada between 2005 and 2008 to achive the following objectives:1- the development of machine learning method for predicting AST from genomic datasets2- Development of simple PCR based AMR gene detection methods

Comments: 'Distinguishable epidemics of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 in different hosts.' Pubmed ID: 24030491. The global epidemic of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 provides an important example, both in terms of the agent and its resistance, of a widely disseminated zoonotic pathogen. Here, with an unprecedented national collection of isolates collected contemporaneously from humans and animals and including a sample of internationally derived isolates, we have used whole-genome sequencing to dissect the phylogenetic associations of the bacterium and its antimicrobial resistance genes through the course of an epidemic. Contrary to current tenets supporting a single homogeneous epidemic, we demonstrate that the bacterium and its resistance genes were largely maintained within animal and human populations separately and that there was limited transmission, in either direction. We also show considerable variation in the resistance profiles, in contrast to the largely stable bacterial core genome, which emphasizes the critical importance of integrated genotypic data sets in understanding the ecology of bacterial zoonoses and antimicrobial resistance.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain SO21
Comments: A recent Salmonella Typhimurium genotype, named ST213, associated with food-animals and humans in Mexico, has emerged as a public health problem due to its multi-drug resistance phenotype and association with human systemic infections. We applied whole-genome sequencing to analyze the genomic basis of the evolution of this recently emerged genotype. Previous studies had revealed that the accessory genome of ST213 strains includes multi-drug resistance IncA/C plasmids and distinctive chromosomal and plasmid prophages, which could encode key adaptive traits that explain the evolutionary paths and ecological success of this Typhimurium genotype. This data is part of a pre-publication release.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. U288
Organism Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. U288
Comments: Over the last decade Salmonella Typhimurium U288 (STU288) has established itself in UK pig production premises.  The microorganism displays enhanced pathogenicity towards pigs compared with other serovars, and as such has proven to be of both economic and veterinary importance.  Also, an outbreak of STU288 in Denmark during 2008 resulted in the death of a number of elderly pepople.  Due to the position of STU288 in the food-chain, knowledge of the genetic make-up of this multi drug resistant strain is essential if efforts are to be made to reduce its prevalence in the UK.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain ISU-SAL243-14
Sequencing Centers: Iowa State University College of Veterinary Medicine
Comments: Five isolates of Salmonella enterica were selected for use in pathogenicity studies in swine followed by whole genome sequencing for evaluation of sequence type, phylogeny, and virulence factor presence. The following serovars are represented in this data set: Typhimurium (two isolates); 4,[5],12:i:- (two isolates); and Derby (one isolate). All isolates were selected from clinical specimens of swine diagnosed with histologic evidence of salmonellosis.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain S10543-93

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain PRKN134 strain SEN134
Isolation Comments: isolated from different sources
Comments: We are sequencing Salmonella enterica strains containing Incompatibility group I1 (Inc I1) plasmids, isolated from different sources. Salmonella is a leading foodborne pathogen causing considerable toll on our health care and economy. Antimicrobial resistance and virulence are key characteristics of clinically relevant Salmonella strains. Mobile genetic elements like Inc I1 plasmids are associated with transfer of genetic determinants of resistance and virulence. Information from this project will give insight into IncI1 variations in different hosts. This would improve our understanding about antimicrobial resistance and pathogenicity of Salmonella strains from different hosts and can give us tools to manage them successfully.

Salmonella enterica serovars typically exhibit a limited range of animal hosts, often referred to as serovar-host specificity. Swine, cattle, and poultry each carry different strains of Salmonella and only certain strains cause infectious disease in these hosts, with the remaining strains carried in a subclinical status or in a commensal relationship. In recent years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported a rise in human foodborne illnesses related to antibiotic resistant Salmonella enterica serovar I 4,[5], 12:i:- largely associated with the consumption of contaminated pork. Salmonella I 4,[5], 12:i:- is a serovar antigenically similar to Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium; however, it lacks the phase two flagellar antigen making it a monophasic variant.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain R8_0784_R1
Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. DT104 strain V105
Isolation Comments: derived isolates, we have used whole-genome sequencing to dissect the phylogenetic associations of the bacterium and its antimicrobial resistance genes through the course of an epidemic
Comments: 'Distinguishable epidemics of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 in different hosts.' Pubmed ID: 24030491. The global epidemic of multidrug-resistant Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 provides an important example, both in terms of the agent and its resistance, of a widely disseminated zoonotic pathogen. Here, with an unprecedented national collection of isolates collected contemporaneously from humans and animals and including a sample of internationally derived isolates, we have used whole-genome sequencing to dissect the phylogenetic associations of the bacterium and its antimicrobial resistance genes through the course of an epidemic. Contrary to current tenets supporting a single homogeneous epidemic, we demonstrate that the bacterium and its resistance genes were largely maintained within animal and human populations separately and that there was limited transmission, in either direction. We also show considerable variation in the resistance profiles, in contrast to the largely stable bacterial core genome, which emphasizes the critical importance of integrated genotypic data sets in understanding the ecology of bacterial zoonoses and antimicrobial resistance.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain LT21
Isolation Source: Salmonella LT22 host) that was constructed into the default tool (P22HTint) for transducing DNA from one Salmonella strain to another, or back crossing mutations into wild-type backgrounds to confirm phenotypes
Isolation Comments: isolated from Salmonella LT22 host) that was constructed into the default tool (P22HTint) for transducing DNA from one Salmonella strain to another, or back crossing mutations into wild-type backgrounds to confirm phenotypes
Comments: The Lilliengeen type (LT) collection of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium has served the scientific community as both a model organism for basic genetic and biochemical pathway research (LT2), a mutator strain (LT7), and a source of bacteriophage (bacteriophage P22 isolated from Salmonella LT22 host) that was constructed into the default tool (P22HTint) for transducing DNA from one Salmonella strain to another, or back crossing mutations into wild-type backgrounds to confirm phenotypes. Inasmuch as LT2, LT7, and LT22 has contributed so much to scientific advancement in the last 65 years, the question arises whether any of the other strains in the Lilliengeen collection have characteristics that could further discoveries in molecular genetics. Our laboratory took the original LT strains and performed microarray assays over a decade ago to determine which of the strains were particularly unique compared to the published LT2 sequence. Here we report the draft genome sequences of the unique Lilliengeen type Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium strains LT1, LT18, LT19, LT20, LT21, and LT22.
Additional Metadata: biomaterial_provider:Salmonella Genetic Stock Centre (SGSC) - University of Calgary;sample_type:Bacterial Culture

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain STM87
Comments: From July to November 2013 more than one hundred human cases of salmonellosis by Salmonella Typhimurium Monophasic variant were diagnosed in Piacenza and linked to pork-meat consumption. Epidemiological studies indicated that pork meat from a local producer was the main cause of the outbreak, while other producer/ pork breeders might have been implicated. PFGE typing detected that all human and the majority of food isolates belonged to the STYMXB.0131 genotype. To highlight the true epidemiological dynamic of this outbreak,a selection of human and food isolates associated with the Outbreak were sequenced using an Illumina MiSeq sequencer with a 2x250 pair-end run. Library preparation was performed using Illumina Nextera XT kits.

Comments: Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium is one of the most prevalent serotypes associated with foodborne infections worldwide . Interestingly S. Typhimurium strains within multi-locus sequence type (MLST) ST313 have been identified as the major cause of invasive diseases in many Sub-Saharan African countries. Previously S. Typhimurium ST313 was rarely reported from regions other than sub-Saharan Africa. Although S. Typhimurium ST313 had previously been isolated from India, the genomics and diversity of this important sequence type were limited Genotypic characterization of S. Typhimurium ST313 isolates circulating in India has been discussed in this study

Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
Organism Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
Sequencing Centers: Genome Sequencing Center (GSC) at Washington University (WashU) School of Medicine
Isolation Comments: isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity
Comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain LT2. This strain was first isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity. It became the principle laboratory strain and many important biochemical and genetic experiments were performed using this strain, including classical phage transduction studies. LT2 contains a plasmid, pSLT, that encodes additional virulence functions. Numerous prophages, some of which contain virulence genes, are inserted into the chromosome of LT2 as compared to related Salmonella.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. D23580
Organism Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium
Comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. D23580.Whereas most non-typhoidal Salmonella (NTS) are associated with gastroenteritis there has been a dramatic increase in reports of NTS-associated invasive disease in Sub-Saharan Africa. Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium isolates are responsible for a significant proportion of the reported invasive NTS in this region. Multi locus sequence analysis of invasive S. Typhimurium from Malawi and Kenya identified a dominant type, designated ST313, currently rarely reported outside Africa. Whole genome sequencing of a multiple drug resistant (MDR) ST313 NTS isolate, D23580, identified a distinct prophage repertoire and a composite genetic element encoding MDR genes located on a virulence-associated plasmid. Further, there was evidence of genome degradation, including pseudogene formation and chromosomal  deletions, when compared to other S. Typhimurium genome sequences. Some of this genome degradation involved genes previously implicated in virulence of S. Typhimurium or genes for which the orthologues in S. Typhi are either pseudogenes or are absent. Genome analysis of other epidemic ST313 isolates from Malawi and Kenya provided evidence for micro-evolution and clonal replacement in the field.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain D23580
Isolation Source: Blood of 26-month child with malaria and anemia
Comments: In order to perform transcriptomic comparison of D23580 and 4/74 strains of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium, we have assembled and carefully annotated both genomes.

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium strain sg_wt7
Comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica genomes from Singapore

Genome Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
Organism Name: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2
Sequencing Centers: Genome Sequencing Center (GSC) at Washington University (WashU) School of Medicine
Isolation Comments: isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity
Comments: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar typhimurium strain LT2. This strain was first isolated in the 1940s by Lilleengen, and typed based on phage sensitivity. It became the principle laboratory strain and many important biochemical and genetic experiments were performed using this strain, including classical phage transduction studies. LT2 contains a plasmid, pSLT, that encodes additional virulence functions. Numerous prophages, some of which contain virulence genes, are inserted into the chromosome of LT2 as compared to related Salmonella.
